Aircraft and spacecraft have become very highly sophisticated machines that can, for the most part, fly themselves with the aid of on-board and/or centralized computer systems that can process thousands of data/pieces of information in a few seconds or even less.
Despite all of these automated capabilities, there still remains a need for pilots and crew aboard these vessels and they, along with the hundreds of thousands of passengers who fly commercially on a daily basis, must rely on the electronic systems and control systems to operate with the degree of reliability and precision that is required for safe flight. So just who has the behind-the-scenes jobs and responsibilities for these flight-critical systems?
This accountability principally rests within the descriptions of avionics and avionics engineers. From a broader perspective, the workshop is focused on the following with respect to aircraft and spacecraft electronics which is covered from the basics with videos, PPTs and the recent issues in aerospace field.
